awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Chemical Synthesis and Biophysical Study of Noncanonical Membrane Lipids
awd_abstract_narration:
With this CAREER Award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Noah Burns at Stanford University. The research improves our fundamental understanding of lipid membranes by synthesizing them from readily available starting materials and then measuring their physical properties. Lipid membranes are universal features of living systems, constituting protective inner and outer barriers of cells. Nature has produced a fascinating array of lipid structures that dictate the function of biological membranes, and organisms devote considerable energy to the synthesis and maintenance of such compositions. Professor Burns is investigating new synthetic reactions to make lipids that are not readily available from natural sources. This research increases our understanding how lipids are formed and how they can be utilized biological and non-biological systems. This research is multidisciplinary and extends beyond the typical boundaries of synthetic chemistry or biology. Through a strong established collaboration, synthetic chemists are working with physical chemists to study the properties of the synthesized lipids, thus tackling larger scientific questions regarding the function of molecules. In order to impact the broader community, Professor Burns and his research group are making use of social media. Platforms such as Twitter and Instagram offer unique opportunities for cross-talk. Twitter (@burnschemistry) is used to communicate findings from the Professor Burns' lab in order to alert the chemical community to exciting new advances. Instagram (@burnschemistry) is used to promote the fun, exciting, and human side of organic chemistry research. The use of social media is intended to excite more young people to consider advanced degrees or careers in chemistry.

Professor Burns is developing selective and efficient syntheses of three classes of noncanonical membrane lipids in order to fully investigate their biophysical properties. Highly unusual polycyclobutane-containing ladderane phospholipids, monocyclohexane- and polycyclopentane-containing tetraether lipids, and polychlorinated sulfolipids have been identified from anaerobic ammonium-oxidizing bacteria, archaea, and freshwater algae, respectively. This research is establishing approaches for accessing each of these three classes of noncanonical membrane lipids. This chemical synthesis is impacting the broader synthetic community by providing new reaction methodologies and new strategies for accessing functional group motifs that are of interest in other contexts. The biophysical properties of natural and non-natural lipids are analyzed utilizing modern techniques to verify self-assembled structures, to measure monolayer density and compressibility, to evaluate permeability of ions and small molecules, and to interrogate membrane thickness and structure. This information has general implications for manipulating membrane properties and designing new soft materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Lipid membranes are universal features of all life. They represent essential barriers that separate living systems from the external world and provide a division between cells and within subcellular compartments. The identity and composition of the lipid molecules that constitute such membranes are tightly regulated to maintain necessary physical properties including fluidity and permeability. The vast majority of membrane lipids in living organisms are phospholipids and glycolipids that contain long linear chains with 16 to 20 carbon atoms. There are interesting outliers, however, and a number of organisms have evolved to produce lipids with radically different chemical structures. The purpose of this NSF-funded work has been to study such structurally unique membrane lipids from three unrelated organisms: four-membered ring-containing ladderane lipids from anammox bacteria, chlorosulfolipids from O. danica algae, and GDGT lipids from archaea. Owing to the difficulty of obtaining large amounts of biological material as well as to the inherent difficulty of separating single species from complex lipid mixtures, these exotic lipid classes had largely eluded physical studies on pure samples prior to these studies. 

Our work has resulted in the development of chemistry for the scalable synthesis of individual natural lipids from each of these classes as well as nonnatural analogues. Access to these molecules then allowed for in-depth investigations into their physical properties. Significant findings included the discovery that: 1) ladderane lipids form highly dense membranes that are significantly less permeable to protons than canonical lipids; 2) chlorosulfolipids can insert into and form lipid bilayers in combination with other naturally occurring lipids; 3) GDGT archaeal lipids are able to fold in half within membranes and adopt a U-shape which is counter to the commonly held belief that they are always membrane-spanning in an O-shape. Furthermore, the novel chemical reactions and molecular structures produced in this work has had broader impacts in syntheses of motifs that occur in drugs and biologically active small molecules as well as in the synthesis of novel polymer materials that alter their properties under mechanical stimuli. We anticipate that this work will prove useful for other synthetic organic chemists in the space of both small molecule and macromolecular science.

In summary, our work has ventured into several underexplored areas of lipid chemistry in probing some of nature's most structurally unique and functionally mysterious lipids. These studies have not only deepened our understanding of lipid membrane physics but has also opened up new pathways for synthetic chemistry, materials science, and biophysical applications.

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2024
Modified by: Noah Burns

Image
  • Structures of the three classes of highly unusual naturally occurring membrane lipids that have been synthesized and analyzed in this work.
    Noah Burns
    Public Domain
    Noah Burns
    Project Outcomes Figure
